awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: R&D Towards Higher Sensitivity Directional Dark Matter Detectors
awd_abstract_narration:
In this era of precision cosmology, measurements suggest that ordinary matter represents only a fraction of the total matter density in the Universe. The rest, whose presence we only infer gravitationally, is unknown in its nature, and is termed dark matter. Particle physics suggests that dark matter comprises relic Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) left over from the Big Bang. Experimental efforts to directly detect WIMPs are extremely challenging due to small interaction probabilities and large backgrounds. The motion of the Earth through the galaxy produces a head-wind of WIMPs. The angular distribution of recoils from WIMP interactions has a ~100% asymmetry, and is modulated at the sidereal rate on account of the Earth's rotation. No known background can mimic this signal. 

The practical implications of the technology being developed for such searches have promising applications to low background alpha and neutron measurements. This work also includes the training of a diverse set of undergraduates and graduate students in increasingly rare small-scale experiments, giving them exposure to a wide range of research experience.

The Directional Recoil Identification From Tracks (DRIFT) experiment leads the field of directional dark matter detection. The intellectual merit of this award resides in DRIFT's sensitivity to this modulated signature, which provides a unique window into one of the most important questions in science today. NSF-funded DRIFT-IId work over the last several years has led to enormous experimental progress. The collaboration is in the final stages of commissioning a new DRIFT-IIe detector. The operation of both detectors will test the viability of long-duration background-free exposures. This award will provide funding to continue the operations of DRIFT-II.

por.por_cntn:
In this era of precision cosmology, measurements suggest that ordinary matter represents only a fraction of the total matter density in the Universe. The rest, whose presence we only infer gravitationally, is unknown in its nature, and is termed dark matter. A leading hypothesis is that dark matter comprises relic Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) left over from the Big Bang. Experimental efforts to directly detect WIMPs are extremely challenging due to small interaction probabilities and large backgrounds that mimic the expected signal. Fortunately, a robust dark matter signature exists to discriminate against backgrounds and definitively identify WIMP interactions. The motion of the Earth through the galaxy produces a head-wind of WIMPs. The angular distribution of recoils from WIMP interactions has a ~100% asymmetry, and is modulated at the sidereal rate on account of the Earth's rotation. No known background can mimic this signal. The intellectual merit of this proposal resides in the Directional Recoil Identification From Tracks (DRIFT) dark matter experiment's sensitivity to this signature, which provides a unique window into one of the most important questions in science today.

NSF-funded DRIFT work over the last decade has led to enormous experimental progress. A thin-film technology was developed to remove ~99.7% of the backgrounds from the central cathode. A long-sought scheme for fiducializing DRIFT detectors was discovered and implemented in the DRIFT-IId detector, resulting in DRIFT running background-free for over 100 days, with two zero backgrounds limits published on the spin-dependent cross-section of dark matter-proton interactions. 

The funds through this NSF award were used to provide partial support for a graduate student to work on a number of R&D projects related to DRIFT. The R&D included research on new negative-ion (NI) gases, discrimination and directionality studies using a 1D cylindrical acrylic TPC, and studies to characterize the properties of a novel 2D TPC readout using timing only. This research led to a discovery of a new NI gas mixtures, SF6+CF4, that includes important features used for fiducializing rare events inside the detector. The other work has implications for scaling up future directional dark matter detectors in a low-cost, robust manner.

The work in this proposal has broader impacts beyond dark matter searches. The use of negative-ion gases could benefit other rare search applications like for neutrino-less double-beta, KK axions and dark-photons. This work also includes the training of a diverse set of undergraduates and graduate students in increasingly rare small-scale experiments, giving them exposure to a wide range of research experience.

Modified by: Dinesh Loomba
